review.title: Better Document-level Sentiment Analysis from RST Discourse Parsing
review.abstract: Discourse structure is the hidden link between surface features and document-level properties, such as sentiment polarity. We show that the discourse analyses produced by Rhetorical Structure Theory (RST) parsers can improve document-level sentiment analysis, via composition of local information up the discourse tree. First, we show that reweighting discourse units according to their position in a dependency representation of the rhetorical structure can yield substantial improvements on lexicon-based sentiment analysis. Next, we present a recursive neural network over the RST structure, which offers significant improvements over classification-based methods.

sections.heading: 2.1 Rhetorical Structure Theory
sections.text: RST is a compositional model of the discourse structure in which elementary discourse units (EDUs) are progressively combined into larger discourse units that ultimately cover the entire document. Discourse relationships can comprise a nucleus and a satellite, or they can be multinuclear. In the example in Figure 1, Unit 1C is the satellite of a relationship with its nucleus 1B; together they form a larger discourse unit involved in a multinuclear CONJUNCTION relationship. The nuclear structure of the RST trees suggests a natural approach to evaluating the meaning of text segments: satellites tend to be less important, and nuclei tend to be more important (Marcu, 1999). This idea has been extensively used in the summary of documents (Gerani et al., 2014; Uze da et al., 2010; Yoshida et al.).

sections.heading: 2.2 Sentiment analysis
sections.text: There is a large literature on sentiment analysis (Pang and Lee, 2008; Liu, 2012), with particular interest in determining the general sentiment polarity (positive or negative) of a document. Bagof word models are widely used for this task, as they provide accuracy that is often very competitive with more complex approaches. Given the marked data, supervised learning can be applied to obtain sentiment weights for each word. However, the effectiveness of supervised sentiment analysis depends on having training data in the same range as the target, and this is not always possible. Moreover, in social science applications, the desired labels cannot directly correspond to positive or negative mood, but can focus on other categories, such as courtesy (Danescu-NiculescuMizil et al., 2013), narrative frames (Jurafsky et al., 2014) or a multidimensional spectrum of emotions (Kim et al., 2012).

sections.heading: 2.3 Datasets
sections.text: The first data set consists of 2000 film reviews compiled by Pang and Lee (2004). We perform a tenfold cross-validation of these data. The second data set is larger and consists of 50,000 film reviews compiled by Socher et al. (2013), with a predefined 50 / 50 split into training and test kits. The documents are rated on a scale of 1-10 and we treat the values ≤ 4 as negative, ≥ 7 as positive and ignore the values of 5-6 as neutral - although in principle nothing prevents the expansion of our approaches to more than two sentiment classes.

sections.heading: 3 Discourse depth reweighting
sections.text: Our first approach to incorporating discourse information into sentiment analysis is based on quantifying the meaning of each unit of text in terms of its depth of discourse, using the Dependency-based Discourse Tree (DEPDT) formulation from previous summary work (Hirao et al., 2013).DEP-DT formalism converts the constituent-like discourse tree into a directional graph of elementary discourse units (EDUs), in a process that provides a close analogy to the transformation of a syntactic constituent word into a syntactic dependency graph (Ku ¼ bler et al., 2009).The DEP-DT representation of the discourse in Figure 1 is shown in Figure 2. The graph is constructed by propagating "head" information into the RST tree; if the elementary discourse unit ei of the satellite in a discourse relationship is led by ej, there is a head-off from ej to ej.

sections.heading: 5 Related Work
sections.text: Other efforts to include RST in sentiment analysis have often focused on intrasentative discourse relationships (Heerschop et al., 2011; Zhou et al., 2011; Chenlo et al., 2014) rather than relationships across the document. Wang et al. (2012) address sentiment analysis in Chinese. Without a discourse sparser, they focus on explicit connectives, using a strategy related to our depth of discourse. Wang and Wu (2013) use manually annotated discourse spares in combination with a sentiment icon that is automatically based on the discourse structure.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: Hoping that the words or phrases that represent general polarity will outweigh those that represent counterpoints or rhetorical concessions, however, with the availability of standard RST discourse savers, it is now easy to incorporate documentation-level structure into sentiment analysis. We show that a simple reweighting approach offers robust advantages in lexicon-based sentiment analysis, and that a recursive neural network can significantly outperform a word classifier.
